criteria: Analysis of Founding Fathers' Philosophy on Natural Rights
Knowledge of Debates on Drafting and Ratification of the Constitution
Understanding of the Bill of Rights
descriptions: No understanding of the ideological origins of the American Revolution is demonstrated.
Demonstrates a very limited understanding of the ideological origins of the American Revolution.
Demonstrates a basic understanding of some of the ideological origins, but lacks depth and detail.
Demonstrates a satisfactory understanding of the main ideological origins of the American Revolution.
Demonstrates a strong understanding of the various ideological origins, including key thinkers and their influence.
Demonstrates a comprehensive and nuanced understanding of the ideological origins, including connections between different philosophies and their impact on revolutionary thought.
Unable to identify or explain the Founding Fathers' philosophy of divinely bestowed unalienable natural rights.
Identifies natural rights with significant inaccuracies or omissions.
Provides a superficial explanation of natural rights with some inaccuracies.
Accurately explains the Founding Fathers' philosophy of natural rights, citing key influences.
Analyzes the nuances of the Founding Fathers' views on natural rights, comparing and contrasting different perspectives.
Critically analyzes the historical context and implications of the Founding Fathers' philosophy of natural rights, including its limitations and contradictions.
Shows no awareness of the debates surrounding the drafting and ratification of the Constitution.
Demonstrates minimal knowledge of the debates, with significant gaps.
Identifies a few key debates but lacks understanding of the underlying issues.
Describes the major debates during the drafting and ratification of the Constitution.
Explains the key arguments and compromises made during the drafting and ratification process.
Evaluates the long-term impact of the debates and compromises on the structure and principles of American government.
Unable to identify or explain the purpose and content of the Bill of Rights.
Identifies some of the rights included in the Bill of Rights but lacks context.
Describes the main provisions of the Bill of Rights with some inaccuracies.
Explains the significance of the Bill of Rights in protecting individual liberties.
Analyzes the historical context and evolution of specific rights in the Bill of Rights.
Evaluates the ongoing debates and interpretations surrounding the application of the Bill of Rights in contemporary society.
